Now you describe four kinds of models of relationship institutions that are used by different countries.
Can you briefly outline them for us?
Sure.
The simplest model is just to take what we already have, which is marriage, and allow same-sex couples to enter this existing institution.

The second model is to create something new, a kind of separate but mainly equal--create a new institution that has the same rights and duties as marriage, but give it another name, and that's what we have in the United Kingdom starting this month, civil partnership.
You have that in Connecticut and Vermont, civil unions; California, domestic partners--after different names around the world.
Third option is to create something new and let everyone, any couple, enter into it.
New Zealand has that.
They call it civil unions.
And a different-sex couple can enter into that there.
And finally, the fourth model is to have something new, open to everyone, but it doesn't give all the rights and duties of marriage.
And that's what they have in France, for example.
